newsitem.title: GERMANY: German metal sector to seek early retirement deal.
newsitem.headline: German metal sector to seek early retirement deal.

text.p: Employers and trade union officials in Germany's huge metal and engineering sector said on Wednesday they wanted an accord that could allow millions of workers to retire early.

The consensus emerged at a first round of talks aimed at overhauling the collective wage bargaining system that the sector, along with most of German industry, has relied on for most of the post-war era.
"Both sides want to secure contractual agreements on pre-retirement working conditions," Werner Stumpfe, speaking for the employers, told journalists after the talks in a hotel in Frankfurt.
One aim of such an agreement would be to create more employment opportunities in an industry which lost more than 100,000 jobs a month last yeazr as firms relocated abroad or reduced capacity.
IG Metall, Germany's largest trade union with some three million members, said earlier it saw agreements allowing early retirment in the sector as an "absolute priority".
"Young workers must be given a possibility of employment in the sector and old workers must be allowed to move into retirement under acceptable circumstances," its chairman said.
IG Metall said it had proposed a model that would allow workers effectively to retire five years early while retaining their full pension entitlements.

Under the scheme, 55-year-old workers would receive 85 percent of their full salary for the last 10 years of their working life. They would then work full-time for five years before being released at the age of 60.
Pension contributions would continue to be paid in full for the last 10 years under the plan, which the union says has the support of the Bonn government.

But Gesamtmetall's Stumpfe said the scheme as it stood was too expensive. A working group of union and employer representatives would look into the issue in more detail before a new meeting scheduled for April 13.

A total of about 4.7 million Germans are now out of work and the collective wage bargaining system that appeared to serve Germany well during the so-called "economic miracle" following the war has come under growing criticism.

Employers in particular argue that sector-wide agreements are too inflexible and do not now work for many firms, particularly small ones and those in relatively new fields such as information technology.

Gesamtmetall wants to have "exemption clauses" built in to collective wage agreements that would, for example, more easily allow companies to save costs by operating at reduced staffing levels when business was slack.

IG Metall opposes such clauses, but has indicated it would be ready to accept so-called "hardship" clauses now used in east German contracts under which, under certain circumstances, firms can reduce wages for a limited period.
A wide-ranging reform of the wage bargaining system is not expected before the end of the year.
